Award.AwardTitle: The Production and Study of Cold Antihydrogen
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports fundamental symmetry tests performed on neutral atoms of antimatter. The project is progressing towards accurate tests of Charge conjugation, Parity, and Time reversal (CPT) invariance with baryons and leptons using precise laser spectroscopy of cold, trapped antihydrogen, as well as investigating the gravitational force on antimatter atoms. Testing the most basic symmetries and notions of physics requires inventing new devices and methods involving atomic physics, plasma physics, nuclear physics, laser physics, non-linear and chaotic dynamics. Two basic methods for producing antihydrogen atoms have been demonstrated previously. The goal of this project is to produce and cool anti-atoms to energies at which they can be trapped for spectroscopy. The experiments are carried out at the CERN laboratory in Geneva, Switzerland at the Antiproton Decelerator (AD) storage ring, a unique and substantial facility built to allow such experiments. Methods to slow, capture and cool the needed antiprotons from the AD were developed as part of this research program.

The broad impact of the program spans from the training of students to the impact of instrument design to the education of the public on antimatter physics. Undergraduate and graduate students are broadly trained in instrument design, experimental physics, and data analysis. Instruments designed for this research have been applied to ICR, NMR and MRI imaging, and trap designs are being used in devices that analyze pharmaceuticals and chemical compounds. The PI presents many scientific colloquiums, popular scientific lectures and high school presentations based upon this research each year.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The long-term goals of this antiproton and antihydrogen research program are extremely precise tests of CPT invariance with baryons and leptons -- using direct, high precision comparisons of the magnetic moments and charge-to-mass ratios of single suspended antiprotons, and using extremely precise laser spectroscopy of cold, trapped antihydrogen. Methods that make it feasible to investigate the gravitational force on trapped antimatter atoms will also be sought.

The intellectual merit of this activity derives first from these fundamental goals, to test what are perhaps the most basic notions of physics, the sort

of "transformational research" that a NRC report recommended to the NSF. The intellectual merit also derives from the wide spectrum of physics

subfields that must contribute to extremely challenging experiments to test the symmetries which are believed to underly particle physics -- including atomic physics, plasma physics, nuclear physics, laser physics, non-linear and chaotic dynamics, etc. Continuous inventions of new methods and devices are required.

 

The broad impact of this program is illustrated by the fact that 5 international collaborations are now using the methods developed by this NSF-sponsored research program to pursue the approach and scientific goals proposed initially as part of this research program. The proposed methods that have been demonstrated include slowing, capturing and cooling these antiprotons by more than ten orders of magnitude in energy, producing antihydrogen atoms in a nested Penning trap, and capturing antihydrogen atoms in a surrounding Ioffe trap. The {\bf broad impact} of this program is further illustrated by CERN's construction and operation of a dedicated storage ring (called the Antiproton Decelerator or AD) so that these antiproton and antihydrogen studies can be pursued, and the recent CERN decision to significantly upgrade this facility to allow 100 times more antiprotons to be trapped.

 

The broad impact of this work is also illustrated by the many hundreds of scientific citations to the reports on this work, the way that principle results are reported not only in leading scientific publications, but also in the scientific press, and in the more popular press. The American Institute of Physics chose the initial antihydrogen observations as the physics story of the year. The PI presents many scientific colloquiums, popular scientific lectures and high school presentations based upon NSF-supported research each year. Students trained in this research program now lead their own research efforts in universities and national labs. Patented solenoid designs are available commercially for ICR, NMR and MRI imaging, and trap designs are being used in devices that analyze pharmaceuticals and chemical compounds.

A single antiproton has just been suspended within a particle trap within which it should be possible to measure the antiproton magnetic moment about 1000 times more precisely than has proven to be possible with other methods. Making this measurement is currently a central objective. During the next grant period the more ambitious objective is to make significant progress towards a precision increase by a factor of one to ten million. It should also be possible to adapt the apparatus to compare the charge-to-mass ratios of the antiproton and proton more accurately than the 9 parts in 1011 comparison completed earlier as a part of this program. A separate beam line will makes it possible to do these measurements parasitically, in parallel with antihydrogen studies.
